citation.article-title: Chthonomonas calidirosea gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic, pigmented, thermophilic micro-organism of a novel bacterial class, Chthonomonadetes classis nov., of the newly described phylum Armatimonadetes originally designated candidate division OP10
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Chthonomonas calidirosea sp. nov.
Chthonomonas calidirosea (ca.li.di.ro′se.a. L. adj. calidus warm, hot; L. adj. roseus -a -um rose-coloured, rosy; N.L. fem. adj. calidirosea hot and rosy).
Cells are non-spore-forming, highly corrugated rods (approx. 0.5–0.7 µm in diameter and 2.5–3.0 µm in length).
Gram-negative, oxidase-negative and catalase-positive; exhibits an oxidative metabolism.
Cell division occurs by binary fission.

Cells grow readily on mono- and disaccharides and on short, branching or amorphous polysaccharides such as dl-arabinose, d-xylose, d-ribose, xylose, d-fructose, d-glucose, d-mannose, d-rhamnose, d-galactose, sucrose, lactose, maltose, trehalose, cellobiose, raffinose, d-N-acetylglucosamine, starch, glycogen, dextrin, CM-cellulose, chitin, xylan, galactomannan, pectin, gellan gum, xanthan and pullulan.
Malic acid and sodium pyruvate also support growth.
Ammonium or yeast extract can act as sole nitrogen sources.
No growth is observed on linear or crystalline polysaccharides.
Optimal growth occurs at 68 °C (range, 50–73 °C) and pH 5.3 (range, pH 4.7–5.8).
Growth on solid gellan-based medium produces pink/rose, opaque colonies with circular and entire edges.
The type strain generates a rose-pink pellicle when incubated statically or in medium with non-optimal pH.
DNA G+C content of the type strain is 54.6 mol% and the quinone system consists of MK-8 (70 %), MK-9 (17 %), MK-7 (10 %) and MK-6 (3 %).
Major fatty acids are 16 : 0 (25.8 %), i17 : 0 (19 %) and ai17 : 0 (13.5 %), with minor amounts of 16 : 1Δ5 (8.8 %), i17 : 1Δ5 (6.8 %) and 5,6-cy-16 : 0 (5.2 %).
The type strain, T49T ( = ICMP 18418T = DSM 23976T), was isolated from geothermally heated soils at Hell’s Gate, Tikitere, New Zealand.
